datasets.name: Sentinel-2 L2A Harmonized
datasets.description: Atmospherically corrected Surface Reflectance. Harmonized to fix DN offset after Jan 2022. Most commonly used for land analysis.

sources.notes: Recommended SR product with harmonized reflectance
sources.code:
import ee
ee.Initialize()

# Load Sentinel-2 SR Harmonized
s2 = ee.ImageCollection('COPERNICUS/S2_SR_HARMONIZED') \
    .filterDate('2023-01-01', '2023-12-31') \
    .filterBounds(ee.Geometry.Point([-122.4, 37.8])) \
    .filter(ee.Filter.lt('CLOUDY_PIXEL_PERCENTAGE', 20))

# Get median composite
composite = s2.median()
print('Band names:', composite.bandNames().getInfo())

from pystac_client import Client
import rioxarray

# Connect to Earth Search
catalog = Client.open('https://earth-search.aws.element84.com/v1')

# Search for Sentinel-2 L2A
search = catalog.search(
    collections=['sentinel-2-l2a'],
    bbox=[-122.5, 37.7, -122.3, 37.9],
    datetime='2023-06-01/2023-06-30',
    query={'eo:cloud_cover': {'lt': 20}}
)
items = list(search.items())
print(f'Found {len(items)} scenes')

# Load a band
item = items[0]
red = rioxarray.open_rasterio(item.assets['red'].href)

import planetary_computer
import pystac_client

# Connect with auto-signing
catalog = pystac_client.Client.open(
    'https://planetarycomputer.microsoft.com/api/stac/v1',
    modifier=planetary_computer.sign_inplace
)

# Search
search = catalog.search(
    collections=['sentinel-2-l2a'],
    bbox=[-122.5, 37.7, -122.3, 37.9],
    datetime='2023-06-01/2023-06-30',
    query={'eo:cloud_cover': {'lt': 20}}
)
items = list(search.items())
print(f'Found {len(items)} scenes')

# Using OData API
import requests

url = 'https://catalogue.dataspace.copernicus.eu/odata/v1/Products'
params = {
    '$filter': "Collection/Name eq 'SENTINEL-2' and "
               "Attributes/OData.CSC.StringAttribute/any(att:att/Name eq 'productType' and att/Value eq 'S2MSI2A') and "
               "ContentDate/Start gt 2023-06-01T00:00:00.000Z and "
               "ContentDate/Start lt 2023-06-30T23:59:59.999Z",
    '$top': 10
}
response = requests.get(url, params=params)
products = response.json()['value']
print(f'Found {len(products)} products')

datasets.name: Sentinel-1 GRD
datasets.description: Ground Range Detected SAR data. All-weather, day/night imaging.

sources.notes: Preprocessed: thermal noise removal, radiometric calibration, terrain correction
sources.code:
import ee
ee.Initialize()

# Load Sentinel-1 GRD
s1 = ee.ImageCollection('COPERNICUS/S1_GRD') \
    .filterDate('2023-01-01', '2023-12-31') \
    .filterBounds(ee.Geometry.Point([-122.4, 37.8])) \
    .filter(ee.Filter.eq('instrumentMode', 'IW')) \
    .filter(ee.Filter.listContains('transmitterReceiverPolarisation', 'VV')) \
    .filter(ee.Filter.listContains('transmitterReceiverPolarisation', 'VH'))

# VV and VH backscatter
composite = s1.mean().select(['VV', 'VH'])
print('Bands:', composite.bandNames().getInfo())

from pystac_client import Client

catalog = Client.open('https://earth-search.aws.element84.com/v1')
search = catalog.search(
    collections=['sentinel-1-grd'],
    bbox=[-122.5, 37.7, -122.3, 37.9],
    datetime='2023-06-01/2023-06-30'
)
items = list(search.items())
print(f'Found {len(items)} scenes')

import planetary_computer
import pystac_client

catalog = pystac_client.Client.open(
    'https://planetarycomputer.microsoft.com/api/stac/v1',
    modifier=planetary_computer.sign_inplace
)
search = catalog.search(
    collections=['sentinel-1-grd'],
    bbox=[-122.5, 37.7, -122.3, 37.9],
    datetime='2023-06-01/2023-06-30'
)
print(f'Found {search.matched()} scenes')

datasets.name: Landsat 9 Collection 2 Level-2
datasets.description: Surface reflectance and surface temperature. Latest Landsat mission.

sources.code:
import ee
ee.Initialize()

# Load Landsat 9 SR
l9 = ee.ImageCollection('LANDSAT/LC09/C02/T1_L2') \
    .filterDate('2023-01-01', '2023-12-31') \
    .filterBounds(ee.Geometry.Point([-122.4, 37.8])) \
    .filter(ee.Filter.lt('CLOUD_COVER', 20))

# Apply scaling factors
def apply_scale(image):
    optical = image.select('SR_B.').multiply(0.0000275).add(-0.2)
    thermal = image.select('ST_B.*').multiply(0.00341802).add(149.0)
    return image.addBands(optical, None, True).addBands(thermal, None, True)

l9_scaled = l9.map(apply_scale)
print('Scenes:', l9_scaled.size().getInfo())

sources.notes: STAC API, includes all Landsat C2 L2

    query={'platform': {'eq': 'landsat-9'}}

import planetary_computer
import pystac_client

catalog = pystac_client.Client.open(
    'https://planetarycomputer.microsoft.com/api/stac/v1',
    modifier=planetary_computer.sign_inplace
)
search = catalog.search(
    collections=['landsat-c2-l2'],
    bbox=[-122.5, 37.7, -122.3, 37.9],
    datetime='2023-06-01/2023-06-30'
)
print(f'Found {search.matched()} scenes')

# Using landsatxplore package
from landsatxplore.api import API

# Initialize with USGS credentials
api = API(username='YOUR_USERNAME', password='YOUR_PASSWORD')

# Search for scenes
scenes = api.search(
    dataset='landsat_ot_c2_l2',
    latitude=37.8,
    longitude=-122.4,
    start_date='2023-06-01',
    end_date='2023-06-30',
    max_cloud_cover=20
)
print(f'Found {len(scenes)} scenes')
api.logout()

    .filterDate('2023-06-01', '2023-06-30') \

datasets.name: USGS 3DEP LiDAR (COPC)
datasets.description: USGS 3D Elevation Program LiDAR in Cloud Optimized Point Cloud (COPC) format. Highest quality elevation data for the US.

sources.notes: STAC API, COG format point clouds
sources.code:
import pystac_client
import planetary_computer

# Connect with auto-signing
catalog = pystac_client.Client.open(
    'https://planetarycomputer.microsoft.com/api/stac/v1',
    modifier=planetary_computer.sign_inplace
)

# Search for LiDAR in area
search = catalog.search(
    collections=['3dep-lidar-copc'],
    bbox=[-122.5, 37.7, -122.3, 37.9]
)
items = list(search.items())
print(f'Found {len(items)} LiDAR tiles')

# Access COPC file
item = items[0]
copc_url = item.assets['data'].href
print(f'COPC URL: {copc_url}')

sources.notes: Direct USGS download, bulk access available
sources.code:
# Via py3dep package
from py3dep import get_map
import geopandas as gpd

# Define area of interest
bbox = (-122.5, 37.7, -122.3, 37.9)

# Get 3DEP data
dem = get_map("3DEP", bbox, resolution=10, geo_crs="EPSG:4326", crs="EPSG:3857")
print(f"DEM shape: {dem.shape}")
print(f"Resolution: {dem.rio.resolution()}")

sources.notes: S3 bucket access, no auth required
sources.code:
import boto3
from pystac import Catalog

# Access STAC catalog
catalog = Catalog.from_file('https://usgs-3dep-stac.s3.amazonaws.com/catalog.json')

# Or direct S3 access
s3 = boto3.client('s3', region_name='us-west-2')
objects = s3.list_objects_v2(
    Bucket='usgs-3dep-stac',
    Prefix='copc/',
    MaxKeys=100
)
print(f"Found {len(objects.get('Contents', []))} COPC files")

datasets.name: USGS 3DEP LiDAR (EPT)
datasets.description: USGS 3DEP LiDAR in Entwine Point Tile (EPT) format for streaming access. Optimized for web visualization.

sources.notes: EPT format for streaming, CORS enabled
sources.code:
# EPT streaming URLs pattern:
# https://s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/usgs-lidar-public/{project}/ept.json

import requests

# Example: Get EPT metadata
ept_url = 'https://s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/usgs-lidar-public/WY_FEMA_East_B4_2019/ept.json'
metadata = requests.get(ept_url).json()

print(f"Points: {metadata['points']:,}")
print(f"Bounds: {metadata['bounds']}")
print(f"Schema: {metadata['schema']}")

# Web-based viewer, no coding required
# 1. Visit https://usgs-lidar.gishub.org/
# 2. Use the EPT search tool
# 3. Draw bounds or search by location
# 4. Load and visualize point clouds
# 5. Extract cross-sections and profiles

# 1. Visit https://coast.noaa.gov/dataviewer/
# 2. Select 'Elevation' > 'Lidar'
# 3. Draw area of interest
# 4. Filter by date/quality
# 5. Download LAZ or XYZ format

datasets.name: ICESat-2 ATL03 Photon Heights
datasets.description: Space-based LiDAR for ice sheet elevation, forest canopy height, and global elevation monitoring.

sources.code:
import earthaccess
import xarray as xr

# Authenticate
earthaccess.login()

# Search for ICESat-2 data
results = earthaccess.search_data(
    short_name='ATL03',
    bounding_box=(-122.5, 37.7, -122.3, 37.9),
    temporal=('2023-01-01', '2023-12-31')
)
print(f'Found {len(results)} granules')

# Download and open
files = earthaccess.download(results[0], './data')
ds = xr.open_dataset(files[0], group='gt1l/heights')
print(ds.h_ph)  # Photon heights

sources.notes: Python package for ICESat-2 data access
sources.code:
import icepyx as ipx

# Initialize query
region = ipx.Query('ATL03', [-122.5, 37.7, -122.3, 37.9], 
                   ['2023-01-01', '2023-12-31'])

# Login and order
region.earthdata_login('username', 'password')
region.order_granules()
region.download_granules('./data')

print(f"Downloaded {len(region.avail_granules())} granules")

datasets.name: GEDI L2A Forest Structure
datasets.description: Global Ecosystem Dynamics Investigation. Space-based LiDAR for forest height and structure mapping.

sources.code:
import earthaccess
import geopandas as gpd
from rasterio.crs import CRS

# Authenticate
earthaccess.login()

# Search GEDI L2A
results = earthaccess.search_data(
    short_name='GEDI02_A',
    bounding_box=(-122.5, 37.7, -122.3, 37.9),
    temporal=('2022-01-01', '2022-12-31')
)

# Download
files = earthaccess.download(results[0], './data')
print(f'Downloaded: {files[0]}')

sources.notes: Monthly aggregated GEDI data in Earth Engine
sources.code:
import ee
ee.Initialize()

# Load GEDI L2A monthly
gedi = ee.ImageCollection('LARSE/GEDI/GEDI02_A_002_MONTHLY') \
    .filterDate('2022-01-01', '2022-12-31') \
    .filterBounds(ee.Geometry.Rectangle([-122.5, 37.7, -122.3, 37.9]))

# Get canopy height
canopy_height = gedi.select('rh_98').mean()
print('Bands:', gedi.first().bandNames().getInfo())

datasets.name: OpenTopography LiDAR
datasets.description: Community repository of high-resolution topographic data. Includes research-grade LiDAR from NSF-funded projects.

sources.code:
import requests
from urllib.parse import urlencode

# OpenTopography API key required
api_key = 'your_api_key_here'
base_url = 'https://cloud.sdsc.edu/v1/AUTH_opentopography/Raster/'

# Get available datasets
params = {
    'datasetName': 'list',
    'API_Key': api_key
}

response = requests.get(base_url, params=params)
datasets = response.json()
print(f"Available datasets: {len(datasets)}")

datasets.name: SRTM 30m Digital Elevation Model
datasets.description: Shuttle Radar Topography Mission DEM. Most widely used global elevation dataset derived from C-band SAR interferometry.

sources.code:
# Manual download via EarthExplorer
# 1. Register at https://earthexplorer.usgs.gov/
# 2. Navigate to Data Sets > Digital Elevation > SRTM
# 3. Select 'SRTM 1-Arc Second Global'
# 4. Draw area or enter coordinates
# 5. Download HGT or GeoTIFF format

import ee
ee.Initialize()

# Load SRTM 30m
srtm = ee.Image('USGS/SRTMGL1_003')

# Clip to area of interest
aoi = ee.Geometry.Rectangle([-122.5, 37.7, -122.3, 37.9])
srtm_clipped = srtm.clip(aoi)

# Get elevation statistics
stats = srtm_clipped.reduceRegion(
    reducer=ee.Reducer.minMax(),
    geometry=aoi,
    scale=30
).getInfo()
print(f"Elevation range: {stats['elevation_min']:.0f} - {stats['elevation_max']:.0f} m")

import rasterio
from rasterio.warp import transform_bounds
import mercantile

# Get tile coordinates for bbox
bbox = (-122.5, 37.7, -122.3, 37.9)
tiles = list(mercantile.tiles(*bbox, zooms=[10]))

# Access terrain tile
tile = tiles[0]
tile_url = f"https://s3.amazonaws.com/elevation-tiles-prod/terrarium/{tile.z}/{tile.x}/{tile.y}.png"

# Read PNG terrain tile (Terrarium format)
with rasterio.open(tile_url) as src:
    data = src.read()
    # Decode Terrarium: elevation = (R * 256 + G + B / 256) - 32768
    elevation = (data[0] * 256 + data[1] + data[2] / 256) - 32768
    print(f"Elevation range: {elevation.min():.1f} - {elevation.max():.1f} m")

datasets.name: TerraSAR-X
datasets.description: High-resolution X-band SAR for detailed terrain mapping, urban monitoring, and interferometry.

sources.notes: DLR archive, requires proposal for research use
sources.code:
# Research access via DLR
# 1. Submit proposal at https://sss.terrasar-x.dlr.de/
# 2. Justify scientific use case
# 3. Access approved data via FTP
# 4. Commercial use requires license
# Limited free data for research/education

sources.notes: Not available in Google Earth Engine
sources.code:
# TerraSAR-X not available in GEE
# Use DLR archive or commercial providers
# Consider Sentinel-1 as free alternative

datasets.name: TanDEM-X Global DEM
datasets.description: Global digital elevation model from TanDEM-X SAR interferometry. Higher resolution and accuracy than SRTM.

sources.code:
# Free 90m TanDEM-X DEM access
# 1. Register at https://download.geoservice.dlr.de/
# 2. Browse TanDEM-X 90m DEM collection
# 3. Download tiles in GeoTIFF format
# 4. No programming API, web download only

# Via Copernicus DEM (based on TanDEM-X)
import requests
from zipfile import ZipFile

# Download Copernicus DEM 30m
base_url = 'https://cloud.sdsc.edu/v1/AUTH_opentopography/Raster/COP30/'
tile_name = 'Copernicus_DSM_COG_30_N37_00_W123_00_DEM.tif'
url = f'{base_url}{tile_name}'

response = requests.get(url)
with open(tile_name, 'wb') as f:
    f.write(response.content)
print(f'Downloaded: {tile_name}')

sources.notes: Search by location and date range

# 4. Select collections by era:
#    - Aerial Photography Single Frames

datasets.name: OpenAerialMap
datasets.description: Community-driven aerial imagery for humanitarian mapping and disaster response. Often post-disaster imagery.

sources.notes: Browse and download interface, API available
sources.code:
import requests
import geopandas as gpd

# Search OAM API
api_url = 'https://api.openaerialmap.org/meta'
params = {
    'bbox': '-122.5,37.7,-122.3,37.9',
    'sort': 'acquisition_start',
    'order': 'desc',
    'limit': 10
}

response = requests.get(api_url, params=params)
data = response.json()

print(f"Found {data['meta']['found']} imagery items")
for item in data['results']:
    print(f"Date: {item['acquisition_start']}, Resolution: {item['gsd']}m")
    print(f"Download: {item['uuid']}")

datasets.name: IGN France Aerial Photography
datasets.description: National aerial photography program from French National Geographic Institute. High-quality orthophotos of France.

sources.code:
# Via WMS service
from owslib.wms import WebMapService

# Connect to IGN WMS
wms_url = 'https://wxs.ign.fr/ortho/wmts'
wms = WebMapService(wms_url)

print(f"Available layers: {list(wms.contents.keys())}")

# Or download via portal:
# 1. Visit https://geoservices.ign.fr/telechargement
# 2. Select BD ORTHO product
# 3. Choose department/region
# 4. Download in ECW or JPEG2000 format

platforms.name: Google Earth Engine
platforms.pricing: Free for research/education; commercial pricing available
platforms.description: Cloud-based geospatial analysis platform. Process petabytes of satellite imagery without downloading. Ideal for large-scale analysis and time series.

platforms.name: AWS Earth Search (Element 84)
platforms.pricing: Free access (AWS egress fees may apply)
platforms.description: STAC-compliant API for accessing satellite data stored on AWS. Cloud-optimized GeoTIFFs enable efficient partial reads. Best for cloud-native workflows.
limitations: AWS egress costs if downloading outside AWS

platforms.name: Microsoft Planetary Computer
platforms.description: Microsoft's planetary-scale geospatial platform with integrated JupyterHub environment. Excellent for ML workflows with pre-configured environments.

platforms.name: Copernicus Data Space Ecosystem
platforms.pricing: Free (processing units limited on free tier)
platforms.description: Official ESA portal for all Copernicus/Sentinel data. Replaced the old Sci Hub. Complete archive with multiple API options.
limitations: Processing units limited on free tier

platforms.name: USGS EarthExplorer
platforms.description: USGS primary interface for Landsat and US aerial data. Complete 50+ year Landsat archive. Bulk download available.

platforms.name: NASA Earthdata
platforms.description: Gateway to all NASA Earth science data across 12 DAACs. Use earthaccess Python package for easy access.
strengths: All NASA data in one place

platforms.name: ASF DAAC (Alaska Satellite Facility)
platforms.description: Primary US source for SAR data. Complete Sentinel-1 archive plus historical SAR missions. On-demand InSAR processing available.

platforms.name: NOAA CLASS
platforms.description: NOAA's archive for weather satellite data including GOES, VIIRS, and historical missions. Order-based retrieval system.

platforms.name: JAXA G-Portal
platforms.description: JAXA's portal for Japanese satellite data including ALOS, GCOM, and Himawari. Primary source for PALSAR data.

platforms.name: USGS 3D Elevation Program
platforms.description: USGS program to collect high-resolution elevation data for the US. Includes LiDAR point clouds and derived DEMs.

platforms.name: NOAA Digital Coast
platforms.description: NOAA's coastal data portal including topographic and bathymetric LiDAR for coastal zone management.

platforms.name: OpenTopography
platforms.description: NSF-funded repository of high-resolution topographic data including research-grade LiDAR collections.

platforms.name: icepyx (ICESat-2 Python)
platforms.description: Python package for accessing and processing ICESat-2 satellite LiDAR data with simplified workflows.

platforms.name: USGS LiDAR Explorer
platforms.description: Interactive web viewer for USGS 3DEP LiDAR data using EPT streaming format. Educational and visualization tool.

platforms.name: TerraSAR-X/TanDEM-X Archive
platforms.pricing: Free for research, commercial licensing available
platforms.description: DLR archive for TerraSAR-X and TanDEM-X SAR data. Requires research proposal for academic access.

platforms.name: TanDEM-X Science Portal
platforms.description: DLR portal providing free 90m resolution TanDEM-X Global DEM for research and education.

platforms.name: UK Environment Agency
platforms.description: UK government portal providing aerial photography and environmental data for England under open license.

platforms.name: Geoportal.de
platforms.description: German federal geoportal providing access to spatial data from all 16 German states including aerial photography.

platforms.name: OpenAerialMap
platforms.description: Community platform for sharing aerial imagery, particularly for humanitarian and disaster response mapping.

platforms.name: IGN Géoservices
platforms.description: French National Geographic Institute providing authoritative spatial data including aerial photography of France.

platforms.name: AWS Terrain Tiles
platforms.description: Pre-processed SRTM elevation data as PNG tiles optimized for web mapping. Uses Terrarium encoding for elevation values.

platforms.name: AWS Open Data
platforms.description: Registry of open datasets hosted on AWS S3. Includes many geospatial datasets with different access patterns.

platforms.name: Copernicus DEM Portal
platforms.description: Official Copernicus Digital Elevation Model portal providing 30m and 90m resolution DEMs based on TanDEM-X.

platforms.name: ASI COSMO-SkyMed
platforms.description: Italian Space Agency portal for COSMO-SkyMed X-band SAR constellation data. Commercial access only.
